comments.author: Diana Galan

comments.text:
We have a thing called an 'inner voice', which is a voice you hear in your 
head.  You can identify it by listening to the voice you hear when you read 
to yourself.  This is the voice you think with, etc., and is entirely 
normal and different from voices generated by hallucinations.  A 
hallucinogenic voice is one in which you cannot determine its location. 
 That is, you cannot tell if it's coming from somewhere outside of your 
brain, or from your brain, and it is often uncontrollable.  You might be 
unsure if someone is speaking around you, or if the voices are accompanied 
with other delusions, if the voices are coming from other sources such as 
the radio/tv/aliens/etc.

Make no mistake, though.  Everyone has an 'inner voice' and it is 
absolutely normal and nothing to be worried about.  Read quietly to 
yourself, and you will 'hear' it in your head.

I have to say, the way you're describing your girlfriend, it sounds much 
more like she has either depression or bipolar disorder than DID. With DID, 
the other personalities are separated from the "main" one's memories, and 
they consider themselves a different person. On the other hand, depression 
and bipolar disorder (along with anxiety disorders) can cause episodes of 
temporary personality shifts--and the lashing out, self-harm, and 
self-abusive thoughts (about you not loving her) sound very much like 
symptoms of depression.

concept that scientific fact is just the explanation that best fits the 
data, which for most things is a lot of data, but on the fringes of science 
where there isn't a ton of it is where errors occur until more data is 
collected. There's also an idea that a certain amount of data is necessary 
to be sure, like 30 data points for bell curve modeling in statistics, or 6 
standard deviations of certainty, which was used to be sure the Higgs Boson 
existed, if I recall correctly.

 No, you're leaning towards what you disagree with and do not want to hear

intentionally and more specifically refers to a disorder and delusions of

biological sexual role of a female fits the precise diagnosis for a 
disassociative disorder. The only way this has been contested in the field

comments.text:
+Letuzfuk
Okay, sure. If you're serious and all, then I'll elaborate. What was once 
called "sexual identity disorder" is now called transgenderism. 
Transgendered people simply feel that their likes, dislikes, and other 
preferences are more compatible with society's expectations of the opposite 
sex than their own. This is not a break from reality, as those expectations 
are only based in arbitrary societal views and not on anything real to 
begin with. It's not perceptual issues, as they don't see or hear or sense 
anything that's not there. It's not disorganized thoughts or speech. It's 
not a separate identity--there's only one, it's just not living up to 
society's rules of what they should enjoy. Not a SINGLE symptom of either 
schizophrenia nor dissociative identity disorder is present in 
transgenderism.

Which leads me to believe that either you have no idea what transgenderism 
is, or you didn't understand this video, or you're trolling. And since this 
is a YouTube comment thread...I'm leaning towards that last explanation as 
the most likely.

top_comment.text:
Separately, a recent study looked at schizophrenia in Westernized countries 
vs the rest of the world and there is a significantly higher amount of 
violent and paranoid delusions in Westernized countries, whereas less 
developed countries (especially those that tend to be more religious) had 
more gentle, supportive voices. People with delusions were much more often 
seen as Oracles or felt that God (a god, etc) was talking through them. As 
a result there was little to no negative stigma associated with it in the 
culture as well. Just an interesting tidbit. I can probably find link to 
the article for anyone interested.﻿
top_comment.author: Tori Holbrook

comments.text:
I think it is undeniable that your environment has a great effect on what 
the hallucinations of a particular person involves. But i would say it is 
entirely dependant on how connected a person is to their surrounding 
culture through their experiences as to whether or not the effect of said 
culture is particularly prominent. Like ethan hunsaker I also have a mother 
with severe schizophrenia, as well as bipolar disorder. Her particular 
hallucinations rather than being centred around anything which could be 
linked to culture or religion are instead much more personal. They involve 
family and friends as well as things which she had personal interest 
in/experience with when not experiencing the illness. I would also like to 
add, addressed to anyone experiencing hardship through having personal 
connection to the condition, that it is by no means something you are 
sentenced to for life. I am personally extremely lucky to have a mum who, 
despite the past which both her and those around her have been through; is 
currently a healthy and happy person, thanks to her use of life changing 
medication. There were many times when I thought i would never have a 
normal mother son relationship again, and so I encourage you to be hopeful 
for the future.
comments.author: Abraham Lincoln (King-of-Mars)

comments.text:
+Ethan Hunsaker that was a really interesting personal commentary on the 
disease. Few people have that kind of perspective and I appreciate your 
candidness about your personal experience. I have seen some of the TED 
talks and they're very personal, but very eye opening to those of us who 
have not had such experience with the disease.
I think the fact that they address the stigma is hugely important. We 
create the stigma as a society for all mental illnesses and it compounds 
the problem in horrible ways.It sounds like you're doing your very best for 
your mom and for education of more people and no one can ask for more. 
Thats awesome.
comments.author: Tori Holbrook

comments.text:
My mom has severe schizophrenia.  Sometimes she does act like God talks to 
her and no one else and sometimes the accusations and things she says would 
be really significant and could garner her a lot of respect if it wasn't 
for the chasm of impossibility that they usually represent; the most 
frequent of which is a claim that she or a family member has some kind of 
terrible disease despite whatever doctors we bring her to. However some of 
the times its people that we know or famous individuals and they are 
usually plotting to murder or other strange and despicable things.  There 
are some great TED talks given by people who have struggled with 
schizophrenia that talk about how they overcame it.
in some of their talks they address the fact that the stigmas they became 
victim of drove the disorder into overdrive and made the voices that much 
more accusatory.  Having lived with someone experiencing all these things I 
can understand how that would work.  It is, however, very hard even though 
I understand the problem to try and treat her with love and respect 
constantly.
comments.author: Ethan Hunsaker

comments.text:
+TheBookworm27 The disorder is associated by firstly the inheritance of the 
malformation, mutated or recessive forms of several genes whose functions 
are interlinked and is said to cause a disruption in the brain chemistry, 
brain formation ect as of late there is no one gene found to cause 
schizophrenia and nor does getting the gene mean you will get the disorder. 
It just increases vulnerability or the risk of obtaining it. Environmental 
factors can induce or onset the genes already inherited for example they 
say if you were born during winter, if your mother had certain virus when 
she was pregnant, if you grew up in an urban environment those things can 
trigger the gene and develop Schizophrenia. In this case, you cannot get it 
if you do not already have a malformation of some of the genes.
Environmental factors can also be responsible for the cause of the 
malformation in the first place during pregnancy but this is the only full 
case where the environment can induce a full conformable change in the 
physical structure of the brain and the genes meaning the environment 
directly caused the mutation of the brain and the genes during pregnancy 
that was not due to inheritance and hence increased the vulnerability of 
obtaining Schizophrenia. 
In all it's the gene and the environment that affect everything. But some 
people have more malformations or recessive genes than others in fact many 
people have the recessive genes, the more  you have the more the risk 
increases and the type of environment you were born, grew up and with which 
you surround yourself also increases the risk of the genes being triggered.

comments.text:
Hey Jared, I am currently in Medical School and I have recently finished my 
rounds with the Psychiatric ward in our teaching hospital. I had to learn 
about Schizophrenia (Sz) to a very complex level. I'm sorry if this is too 
long / too complicated to understand. If you need help with understanding 
this, please reply and I can help

There are two factors that can cause Sz: genetics and environmental. I will 
go into (some) detail in both.

1. Genetics. Washington University in St. Louis has done a study recently 
that has found 11 gene candidates for causing Sz. Currently, there are only 
2 groupings that 99% of the population of Sz's are classified in under the 
DSM-V. However, this study has found EIGHT groupings instead of just two 
(one grouping has a 100% chance of acquiring Sz!). These gene markers are 
found on chromosomes 1, 6, 8, 11, 13, and 22. These genes all play a role 
in neural plasticity (how our brain can reform itself to experience and 
injury) as well as GABA, glutamate, acetylcholine, and cortex development. 
In short, these "bad" genes affects how the brain is formed. A good example 
of this is CT scans showing enlarged lateral ventricles, which shows brain 
deterioration!

When the video talks about twins, they don't involve the whole picture. 
Twins that share the same placenta have a 40-50% concordance rate (where 
both twins will get Sz). However, if there is a split placenta, there is 
only a 10% chance of concordance. This means that if twins don't share the 
placenta, there's a 90% chance that the other twin WILL NOT be affected by 
the first twin if he/she has Sz.

Simple brain plan of getting Sz:
a. loss of brain stem arousal neurons (DA, NE, Glu, and GABA)
b. negative symptoms in the prefrontal cortex
c. loss of inhibitory feedback to limbic systems (amygdala and hippocampus)
d. induction of positive symptoms

2. Environmental causes. This one is easier to grasp. There are four points 
in one's life where he/she can get Sz: in utero, at birth, childhood, and 
adolescence. This means by your mid-twenties, you are in the clear for 
getting Sz. In utero, there are several factors that can cause (or make the 
fetus more susceptible to) Sz. One is maternal malnutrition/drug use. The 
fetus is MOST susceptible at the end of the 2nd trimester to drugs and 
malnutrition. The second is viral infections. Studies have shown that when 
a viral epidemic occurs, there is a sharp spike in Sz cases in children 
born during the epidemic because the mother caught the virus. A heavy viral 
load (very bad case of the cold, for example) increases the rate of Sz 
vulnerability/acquisition 10x! The last genetic component is paternal age. 
The older the father is during conception, the higher the chance of 
developing Sz (and other disorders as well.)

During childhood and adolescence, there are several other factors. First, 
there is severe abuse/neglect. Children that were born in a stressful and 
harmful environment have a much higher chance of getting Sz (please note 
that not every child put in this kind of environment will get Sz.) Speaking 
of stress, a high stress load can put a child/adolescent in a position to 
getting Sz. This is especially true if the child is going through a tough 
economical position where the parents lose jobs, have to downgrade 
lifestyle, etc. Lastly, there are several studies of Cannaboid that links 
risks of acquiring Sz-related psychosis. Cannabis glutamate and GABA 
receptors and, if an adolescent abuses it, will change brain 
neuroplasticity that will cause Sz.

I know this is a lot to read, but I hope you find this helpful. Sz is a 
very complicated disease that needs a lot of studying to be done. Hope I 
painted a clearer picture for you!

comments.text:
Luckily we have multi-core multi-threaded processing brains, otherwise 
these things would be far more horrendous because of this. Computers crash 
due to various errors that I bet a lot of them are like errors that occur 
in our brains.

Imagine if all we had going on in our brains is a single process and you 
get a panic attack... a panic attack is simply some sort of triggered fear 
response method that calls itself so what you have is a recursive algorithm 
that for some reason the solution signal is never being sent. In other 
words the method call is too early or the signal sender or its pathway is 
somehow damaged. So if we had only 1 thread that would just intensify as 
our bodies functions shut down from not having their system regulated.

Luckily what happens is that we have other threads that can shut down or 
trigger the signal to shut down that method. Or we can generate a new 
pathway for the the signal to reach there. Or we can rebuild the signal 
sender or kick it into functioning at some point.

Alot of brain scientists say it's dangerous to compare brains to 
computers... I think that is rather silly considering these types of 
systemic problems can be diagnosed and understood probably better by 
someone who knows about programming than most brain scientists... The only 
real difference I see is taking into account biological abilities that are 
currently not available to technological systems... This is similar to 
genetics imo... I've thought about challenging some programmers to come up 
with a program and programming language which can only use 16 terms that 
can create the physical structure of a known animal... I'd be satisfied 
with just a base level skin deep model, but if they can get it that far I'd 
bet they'd be able to model an entire living organism with it and I'd put 
money on it that if you then compared how that works to DNA you'd have a 
lot of answers open up to you in that realm... but meh, I doubt anyone is 
going to do that lol ^.^

comments.text:
HBO did a great documentary on it (back when it was still called Multiple 
Personality disorder): /watch?v=B0LNyXsErb8

Some of the most interesting things in the documentary:
1. A woman with different handwriting for her different personalities.  On 
one level, this should be easy to fake, but it should be much harder to 
fool a professional whose job it is to analyze and verify handwriting, and 
handwriting experts swear up and down that the things written in her 
journal are written by different people.
2. A man whose dog stays out of the living room when his owner is home, but 
comes into the room when the child persona takes over.  What's particularly 
interesting about this is that the dog leaves right BEFORE the transition 
back, as though he can sense it.
3. A woman whose vision is drastically different for her different 
personalities.  Her glasses are strong enough that by all accounts, she 
either shouldn't be able to see with them on, or shouldn't be able to see 
with them off.  But in her main personality, she needs the glasses, and in 
her child personality, she has 20/20 vision.

I'm led to believe that these sorts of things are not unique to just those 
individuals.  I can't say with certainty whether or not it's all bunk, but 
if it is fake, then I'd love to hear another reasonable explanation for the 
stuff like the handwriting/dog/vision.

and never thought about it until I saw the Crash Course episode on it. The 
video was posted about a week after I had stepped out onto my porch atop a 
hill and immersed myself in the vivid perception of having dictatorial 
authority. When I reluctantly decided to watch the video several days 
later, I was absolutely shocked to see the degree to which I matched the 
description of the disorder. I suppose you could say it was until after I 
had learned about the nature of bipolar disorder that I had thought to 
exercise the possibility that "I'm so bipolar".
comments.author: Montpelier Montgomery

captions.text:
It's perhaps the most stigmatized and misunderstood
psychological disorder of them all, even among

psychologists. Maybe because it's pretty rare,
affecting about 1% of the population, schizophrenia

causes more anxiety in the media, in the public, and
even in doctors' offices than any other mental illness.

As a result, its sufferers have often been
shunned, abused, or locked up. And among the

many fallacies that surround the disorder
is simply what it means. The word "schizophrenia"

literally means "split mind" but contrary
to popular belief, the condition has nothing

to do with a split in personality or multiple
personalities.

The term refers instead to what's sometimes
called a "split from reality." Multiple Personality

Disorder, now known as Dissociative Identity
Disorder, is a totally different type of condition,

a kind of dissociative disorder. And these
too, are shrouded in misconceptions, partly

because they were the subject of, probably,
the greatest psychological hoax of all time.

While many of us can relate on some level
to the emotional swings, nervousness, and

compulsions that come with mood and anxiety
disorders, it can be a lot harder for those

without direct experience to relate to the
symptoms of schizophrenia and dissociation.

Unfortunately we tend to fear and avoid what
we don't understand in each other, whether

it's a friend of family member or just some
stranger on the bus. But thankfully part of

the psychologist's job is to demystify the
things that can happen in our heads, and as is

often the case, understanding may be the key
to compassion.

Schizophrenia is a chronic condition that
usually surfaces for men in their early to

mid-20s, and for women in their late 20s.
For some the disorder comes on gradually,

but for others it could arise more suddenly,
perhaps triggered by stress or trauma, although
no event can actually cause the disorder.

Once thought of as a single discrete condition,
schizophrenia is now included in the DSM-5

as a point on a spectrum of disorders that
vary in how they're expressed and how long
they last, but they share similar symptoms.

Schizophrenia Spectrum Disorders are currently
thought of as characterized by disorganized

thinking; emotions and behaviors that are
often incongruent with their situations; and

disturbed perceptions, including delusions
and hallucinations.

They all involve a kind of loss of contact
with reality on some level. The resulting

behaviors and mental states associated with
this break from reality are generally called

"psychotic symptoms" and they usually impair
the ability to function.

When someone's experiencing psychotic symptoms,
their thinking and speech can become disorganized,

rambling and fragmented. This tendency to
pick up one train of thought and suddenly

switch to another and then another can make
communication painfully difficult.

People exhibiting these symptoms can also
suffer a breakdown in selective attention,

losing the ability to focus on one thing while
filtering others out.

In extreme cases, speech may become so fragmented
it becomes little more than a string of meaningless

words, a condition given a name that sounds
like its own kind of non sequitur, "word salad."

Classic schizophrenia is also often marked
by delusions or false beliefs not based in

reality. These delusions can be rooted in
ideas of grandeur like "I'm the queen of England!"

or "I won an Olympic gold medal for the luge!"
Or they can become narratives of persecution

and paranoia, believing your thoughts and
actions are being controlled by an outside

force or that you're being spied on or followed
or that you're on the verge of a major catastrophe.

And there are some complicated variations
on these delusions, like feeling that you've

died or don't exist anymore or that someone is madly in
love with you or that you're infested with parasites.

Delusions of one kind of another strike as
many as four out of five people with schizophrenia.

While some delusions can seem fairly logical,
they can also be severe and bizarre and frightening.

Unfortunately maybe the most memorable examples
of people suffering from severe delusions

come from serial killers and yeah, while Son
of Sam did claim that he was taking orders

from his neighbor's dog, that kind of stuff
is in the tiny, tiny, tiny minority.

Brian Wilson of The Beach Boys and Syd Barrett
of Pink Floyd both suffered psychotic symptoms.

And then of course there's John Nash, the
Nobel Prize winning American mathematician
and subject of the movie "A Beautiful Mind."

Through proper treatment, some people with
schizophrenia have not only learned to live

with their illness but also made fantastic
creative contributions to the world.

Maybe people with schizophrenia also suffer
from perceptual disturbances, or sensory experiences

that come without any apparent sensory stimulation,
like hallucinations. This is when a person

sees or hears something that isn't there, often lacking
the ability to understand what is real and what isn't.

Auditory hallucinations, or hearing voices,
are the most common form, and these voices

are often abusive. It's as if you're inner
monologue, that conversation that you have

with yourself or the random things that float
through your head, were somehow coming from

outside of you. It's as if you couldn't sort
out whether the voices in your mind were internal
and self-generated, or external and other-generated.
To me, it sounds terrifying.

Other common symptoms include disorganized,
abnormal, or incongruent behavior and emotions.

This could mean laughing when recalling a
loved one's death or crying while others are

laughing. Acting like a goofy child one minute, then
becoming unpredictably angry or agitated the next.

Movements may become inappropriate and compulsive,
like continually rocking back and forth or
remaining motionless for hours.

Broadly, most psychotic symptoms fall into
three general categories traditionally used

by psychologists: positive, negative, and
disorganized symptoms.

Positive symptoms are not what they sound
like. They're the type that add something

to the experience of the patient. Like, for
example, hallucinations or inappropriate laughter
or tears or delusional thoughts.

Negative symptoms refer to those that subtract
from normal behavior, like a reduced ability

to function, neglect of personal hygiene,
lack of emotion, toneless voice, expressionless
face, or withdrawal from family and friends.

Finally, disorganized symptoms are those jumbles
of thought or speech that could include word

salad and other problems with attention and
organization.

Symptoms like these are useful in diagnosing
a disorder on the schizophrenia spectrum,

but there's a physiological component too.
Like many of the disorders we've talked about,

schizophrenia has been associated with a number
of brain abnormalities.

Post mortem research on schizophrenia patients
has found that many have extra receptors for

dopamine, a neurotransmitter involved in emotion
regulation and the brain's pleasure and reward centers.

Some researchers think that overly responsive
dopamine systems might magnify brain activity

in some way, perhaps creating hallucinations
and other so-called positive symptoms as the

brain loses its capacity to tell the difference
between internal and external stimuli.

For this reason, dopamine blocking drugs are
often used as anti-psychotic medications in

treatment. Modern neuroimaging studies also
show that some people with schizophrenia have

abnormal brain activity in several different
parts of the brain.

One study noted that when patients were hallucinating,
for example, there was unusually high activity

in the thalamus, which is involved in filtering
incoming sensory signals. Another study noted

that patients with paranoid symptoms showed
over-activity in the fear processing amygdala.

So, schizophrenia seems to involve not just
problems with one part of the brain, but abnormalities
in several areas and their interconnections.
But what might be causing these abnormalities?

Earlier I mentioned how a stressful event
might trigger psychotic symptoms for the first

time, even though it can't actually create
the disorder. Psychologists call this the
"diathesis-stress model."

This way of thinking involves a combination
of biological and genetic vulnerabilities

-- diathesis -- and environmental stressors
-- stress -- that both contribute to the onset

of schizophrenia. This model helps explain
why some people with genetic vulnerability

might not always develop schizophrenia and
why the rates of schizophrenia tend to be

higher with some degree of poverty or socioeconomic
stress.

And it seems too that there is some kind of
genetic predisposition for the disorder. The

one-in-a-hundred odds of developing schizophrenia
jumped to nearly one in ten if you have a

parent or sibling with the disorder, with
about 50/50 odds if that sibling is an identical
twin, even if those twins were raised apart.

One recent landmark seven year study looked
at genetic samples across 35 countries, examining

more than 35,000 people with schizophrenia,
and another 110,000 without the disorder.

The study identified more than 100 genes that
may increase the risk of schizophrenia. As

expected, some of these genes involve dopamine
regulation, but others are related to immune

system functioning. Researchers continue to
tease out what is exactly going on here, but

many are hopeful that these new findings will
lead to better treatment.

Clearly, schizophrenia is a challenging disorder
to live with and one that's hard for outsiders

to understand, but maybe even more rare and
more elusive are the dissociative disorders.

These are disorders of consciousness, called
dissociative because they're marked by an

interruption in conscious awareness. Patients
can become separated from the thoughts or

feelings that they used to have, which can
result in a sudden loss of memory or even
change in identity.

Now, we might all experience minor dissociation
at times, like maybe the sense that you're

watching yourself from above, as in a movie,
or like you're driving home and get so zoned

out that suddenly you find yourself in front
of Taco Bell thinking, like, "How did I get here?"

Those things would generally fall into the
normal range of dissociation, but most of
us don't develop different personalities.

Dissociative disorders come in several different
forms, but the most infamous of the bunch

is probably Dissociative Identity Disorder.
This has long been known as Multiple Personality

Disorder and, yes, it is a thing. It's a rare
and flashy disorder in which a person exhibits

two or more distinct and alternating identities
and the best known case was that of Shirley

Mason, whose story was famously rendered in
the 1973 best seller "Sybil" and later in
a popular mini-series.

The book was marketed as the true story of
a woman who suffered great childhood trauma

and ended up with 16 different personalities,
ranging from Vicky, a selfish French Woman,

to handyman Syd, to the religious and critical
Clara.

The book became a craze and within a few years
reported cases of multiple personality skyrocketed
from scarcely 100 to nearly 40,000.

Many believe the book was essentially
responsible for creating a new psychiatric

diagnosis. It turns out though, Sybil's story
was a big fat lie.

Yes, Shirley Mason was a real person and one
with a troubled, traumatic past and a number

of psychological issues. As a student in New
York in the 1950s she started seeing a therapist

named Connie Wilbur and taking some heavy
medications. And somewhere in there, maybe

because she was coaxed, or maybe because she
wanted more attention, Shirley started expressing
different personalities.

Dr. Wilbur built a career and a book deal
out of her star patient, even after Shirley

confessed that her split personality was a
ruse.

The Sybil case is a powerful reminder that
we really don't understand dissociative disorders

very well or even know if they're always real.
Indeed, some people question if Dissociative

Identity Disorder is an actual disorder at
all.

But some studies have shown distinct body
and brain states that seem to appear in different

identities, things like one personality being
right handed while the other is left handed,

or different personalities having variations in their eye
sight that ophthalmologists could actually detect.

In these cases, dissociations of identity
may be in response to stress or anxiety, a
sort of extreme coping mechanism.
Either way, the debate and the research continue.

Today we talked about the major symptoms associated
with the schizophrenia spectrum disorders, including

disorganized thinking, inappropriate emotions
and behaviors, and disturbed perceptions.

We also discussed brain activity associated
with these disorders and talked about their

possible origins including the diathesis stress
model.

You also learned about dissociative disorders,
and Dissociative Identity Disorder in particular,
and the scandal that was the Sybil case.

Thanks for watching, especially to all of
our Subbable subscribers who make Crash Course

possible. To find out how you can become a
supporter, just go to subbable.com.

This episode was written by Kathleen Yale,
edited by Blake de Pastino, and our consultant

is Dr. Ranjit Bhagwat. Our director and editor
is Nicholas Jenkins, the script supervisor

is Michael Aranda. He is also our sound designer
and the graphics team at Thought Cafe.

title: Schizophrenia & Dissociative Disorders: Crash Course Psychology #32
